positive.review: Don't let the graphics fool you. This game is really good! It combines elements from Final Fantasy Tactics (battles, jobs), Darkest Dungeon (perma-death, dungeon structure), D&D (skill trees, skill checks), and, dare I say, does so flawlessly. I've wanted a great, deep guild management game for a while now and this game hit the nail on the head. Since I'm an old man, I really love the Flash game-style graphics. It feels like you found a Newgrounds game that actually had the resources to make a brilliant product. This game is definitely worth your money.

Scratches an XCOM-but-as-a-fantasy-rougelite sort of itch, 35 hours deep and still mid-level (Though i wander off and do housework and cook sometimes). I'm having lots of fun working if it's possible to imbalance the game significantly by over-leveraging character development variances but also becoming quite fond of the members of the 5 parties I have rolling around righting wrongs all over the place. 

So far gameplay complexity and combat scale is grand enough, standard turn based strategic combat grid encounters, short and snappy, with exploration and opportunities to rest between with a home base to develop alongside your characters with the loot you bring home. Positive so far but higher level is where these sorts of systems start to creak so if I remember to I will circle back and update once I have got that far. Be wary of the odd encounter that is there to keep you humble. Usually it is a random encounter which just happens to exploit a gap in your party skill mix somehow and can quickly lead to the death of a poorly positioned light or medium armoured party member. This game does not mess about with punishing leaving any individual overexposed and vulnerable. If it can kill someone it will. It will even swarm to a vulnerable threat over closer targets. I do it all the time to the enemy so I actually respect that. 

Base developments is fun but chat interactions are somehow painful, the timing windows of the click through's to proceed and how long before they appear or something like that is the root. I just know the bit of me that hates having unresolved alerts hates the bit of me that wants to refuse to engage in npc interaction chat at all unless it seems like it will drive the plot forwards. 

Has a neat longer mission structure mechanic where groups of characters head out to complete a task for a few days and are unavailable for combat during their absence. Benefits of completing these include XP, loot, specific abilities, etc.

Now, the demand for a space bar press now and then can annoy. Despite being a completely mouse driven game it now and then asks for exclusively key input. I know I could probably mess with settings for this but it seems so clunky and unneeded and somehow interrupts your flow so much. Not sure why this has frustrated me so. I didn't realise it was bothering me that much until I started typing about it. 

I'm really not a huge fan of the art style, I am here for something which puts me in mind of the 4th edition of a very, very famous ttrpg. The style just jars a bit and makes me feel like I am playing a Delicious in Dungeon licence. It works perfectly well at achieving what it sets out to do, just not my thing.

So a very fun, tactical turn and grid based combat game that has more in common with a ttrpg like D&D than it does the aforementioned XCOM, and because it does that well I am willing to put up with some clunky design choices and art which doesn't work for me. Overall this is pretty high praise as I can be really fussy, if I can be bothered to stick around for a bit under a week of work despite the annoyances it is probably a very good game. Going back to play it now.

I just beat the game and I think this game was amazing! I enjoyed making my own party members a lot. However I do wish the game had more customization options as we can already change the color of the eyes and hair along with what the style of both are. But yet, I wish that we could at least change the clothing color of the character too since a lot of my adventurers looked silly with the mismatching colors. Also in the game some accessories actually appear on your character, so I think it would have been nice to have some sort of vanity wardrobe kind of system where we could add them on to our character without granting them the effects of the coresponding accessory. I enjoyed the game play a ton, yet when it came to auto-battling I was a bit baffled about how my party fought so stupidly while the enemy fought so strategically. I know that auto-battle is a luxury and that people want a challenge, but I wish that our party actually made better choices while it was on. The maps were fun and all and I really did enjoy the side quests. Now I don't have any problems with the recruitable special characters, but once you got them they felt flat and bland. I feel like the game was heavily benefit if they all got their own unique story quest line like (Spoiler alert) Ferdinand the talking sword's quest line. As once you get them they just sit in your party accept for one exception which was (Spoiler) Misasa. I really think it would have been nicer if they were included more in the story or as I said before get their own quest line. Also I know that the developer said they wouldn't add mods and all, but I think it also would be nice if we could import our own sprites for hair, faces, clothes, etc. as we can already do that with the portraits. Sort of like a character maker.

Our Adventurer Guild does a lot of things right, with some annoyances along the way. However, a lot of these annoyances can be easily mitigated thanks to the dev's foresight in allowing you to customize a variety of options, both in and out of game.

1) Lots of classes - it's pretty standard fare, especially if you're familiar with pen and paper RPGs. Warriors, defenders, mages, clerics, paladins, so on. There are single-purpose classes as well as hybrids (arcane knights, bards, paladins), plus higher tier versions of the base classes that unlock new abilities and increase stat growth. I'm not going to get into how useful each class is, because there's too many factors that affect this - difficulty settings, your luck in getting "good" adventurers from the tavern, so on. I will say, I found all the classes useful in some capacity - either for stat growth or actual combat ability. I wish that you could create your own mix of abilities from various classes (skill points invested in skills that aren't shared between classes when you re-class an adventurer are refunded, and those skills removed), but I suppose the hybrids do this to some degree.

2) There's plenty of unlocking you can do with the guild itself - new and better facilities that allow equipment upgrades, mood management for your adventurers, so on. It does take a while to get to a fully unlocked guild, and these upgrades are generally gated by your guild's renown level (which, generally, is gated by completing certain story missions).

3) Characters. You're going to be managing lots of adventurers - recruiting, training, organizing into parties, equipping, managing their mood, so on. If you're playing the game without any adjustments or customization - just purely vanilla - you're at the mercy of RNGesus, pure and simple. The difference between acquiring a band of average adventurers with mediocre growths and talents with one mega-talented adventurer with incredible talents and growths is overwhelming. The dev was clearly aware of this and so provided a host of ways for you to get around this if you wanted - you can edit .ini files, you can adjust in-game sliders, you can savescum stat growth rolls (you even get 1 free reroll per level up if you want to try for better rolls). There's even an optional 'scouting' system that lets you create custom adventurers with a point-buy system (for a pretty hefty fee, of course).

4) I think the art style is charming. It has a unified aesthetic, allows some character customization, and even shows the weapons your characters have equipped on their combat models. The facial expressions on the characters are pretty great, too. I don't understand why people complain about this in their reviews when you can clearly see them on the store page. If you're that much of a graphics slut then move on and play something else.

5) RNG in general. You're going to get angry at the RNG at some point, I'm sure. That's just how chance works, at times. But if you don't like it, you have a plethora of ways to adjust it until you're satisfied. I personally really like the Bravery system - adventurers can expend a rolling resource - Bravery Points - to increase hit chance, take extra actions, reroll failed skill checks. It helps mitigate the RNG and, with judicious use, can allow you to survive otherwise incredibly punishing encounters.

6) Combat. Generally it's enjoyable, but I have a few complaints here since you spend so much time engaged in it: a) All battle maps seem to be the same size; b) generally the most efficient way of dealing with any combat is to just delay for a turn or two, wait for the enemies to approach, then take them down. This changes a bit as enemies get increased movement ranges and abilities that basically hit you anywhere on the map, which is an annoyance in and of itself; c) boss battles almost always boil down to 'Kill the boss before his infinite adds overwhelm you'. The Bravery system, mentioned above, goes a long way to ensuring the combat is enjoyable.

Overall, the dev did a great job. Our Adventurer Guild is an amazing one-man piece of work that, due to the gameplay and the customization options provided, is sure to scratch a tactical itch many of us have been feeling since the PS1.

I played only a little bit of this and decided it was not for me just because of the art style. But don't let that dissuade you as there is a lot to like. Easy to say that this is budget FF Tactics, but underneath there is a very fleshed out management and progression system with some decent turn based combat. If you are looking for an alternative to games like FF Tactics, can't really go wrong for $20AUD.
I love this game. I was not expecting the amount of little side stories and adventurer interactions as there were. I played solely on the steam deck and had no problems.

Really impressed by this game.

It takes features from D&D, Darkest Dungeon, FF tactics and gives it a layer on top of a guild management setup.

One thing I founds really good, is that you can choose static or dice roll for level up's. Static growth is great for playing the game however you can still level up stats in quests or potions etc so no big deal if you try to farm dicerolls.

If you love strategy games. Then this game will be up to your alley. This game have both controlling your adventurers in combat and managing your guild. 

After completing the game, there are difficulty options that will make things more challenging. The replayability is good. This game is a hidden gem.
Easy to understand, funny dialogs and overall just lovely
This is a good game to relax and play even though the first boss is a little rough once you know what you are doing its very fun.

A great turn based game that allows the individual squad members to have their own story and events. Allowing for some unique members with special stats or abilities rather than just tank, healer, dps etc. The gameplay is fun, but gets tedious when you have to farm. Which you will do a decent amount, so just farm some low level dungeons with auto battle on.  

TLDR- Fun turn based game that allows for unique squad members. Gameplay is fun, but can be tedious because of the need to farm. Still fun though. Don't enable doom clock.

Found this game on accident when it popped up under a recommendation tab. Really scratched the "level up, get stronger" itch. Good music, satisfying sound effects, and the leveling/gearing always seems like it's giving you enough each step of the way.

Fun to play. In-game dialogue isn't something to write home about, but the gameplay has depth because you have freedom to choose what skills your characters can specialize in their respective job. (If you don't like their job class, you can change their job.) You can also customize difficulty if you are into a more hardcore experience.

Don't let the simple (but cute) graphics fool you!

This is by far one of the greatest games I have played. The story isn't super complex, but it has some nice surprises and a very deep emotional depth that left me happily surprised.

For those who love games like Final Fantasy Tactics or Troubleshooters, this game is a must-buy. It truly shows that good writing and hard work are still the best qualities for making a great game.

Buy the game and the DLC for sure; this company deserves the support. I can only hope for more DLC or even a second game.

Congrats to all the developers and thanks for this experience.

The game gave me isekai vibe from anime/manga. The adventurers have lots of traits. These traits could lead you to different events, humor moments, unique event result, class compatibility, advantage/disadvantage, lover pairing compatibility and many more. You decide how you progress with the story, which quest to do, event choice, who you are going to recruit, which class your adventurer should be working on (starting class can be changed) or do scouting to customize what kind of adventurer you want, party members, and many more. There are some ideas I want to try on New Game+ later with the party mix and character traits later. I think the customization on adventurers, difficulty, different approach to play, and DLC give replay value. For example: I want to make pure monk party on next game, I want solo every quest on highest difficulty, I want to build a character that OHKO everything, I want to recreate adventurer party from certain anime, etc.

The plot is really interesting, you have to start from nothing, rebuild the guild's reputation, search trainers, solve the mystery of the former guild master's death.

Our Adventurer Guild quickly turned into one of my favorite games -- what a pleasant surprise. Like others have said, it's a marriage of XCOM, Final Fantasy Tactics, and a little bit of D&D anime fantasy. GreenGuy, this game was a treat. Thank you for the fun!
Nothing about this game is remarkable, but by combining a decent story with a decent art style and a great progression system it somehow turns out far better than the sum of its pieces.

Nicht von der simplen Comic-Grafik täuschen lassen. Neben den üblichen Charakteren und Quest (besiege den Bösen, sammle Gegenstände) bietet das Spiel ist eine gelungene Mischung verschiedener RPG-Elemente. Ein D20 entsprechendes Skill- und Skillcheck-System, taktische Kämpfe wie in den alten Goldbox D&D RPG und permadeath Option.
Dazu kommt das Guildmanagement, um die Abenteurer sinnvoll zu Teams zusammenzufassen und bei Laune zu halten.

Barely scratched the surface, but wow what a game. I almost didn't give it a shot because of the art style when you're in adventure mode but I'm really glad I gave it a chance. Wonderful game so far and I can't wait to see where it goes and how it gets updated

This game was quite fun. I loved the little stories, the characters. I don't normally play isometric strategy but gave this one a shot because I think there was a demo offered during like Nextfest or something. I'm glad I did. The dlc was released somewhat recently (I still have to play it) but I'm sure it'll be fun. I look forward to the next game this developer releases.
Good TB combat + some guild management, highly configurable custom difficulty

Don't let the admittedly amateurish art fool you into backing out, the game has a lot of depth and sovl attached to it. You can add your own portraits into the game ala classic CRPGs if you want better looking portraits. If you're a boomer like me and played Artix Games... games, then this artstyle is actually pretty nostalgic.

One of those games that uses a pretty popular concept in another type of media (Adventurer Guilds in anime), yet is not popular and criminally underutilized in the gaming sphere. 
A lot of depth, and fun.

truly an indie gem,

like other reviews have said its a mix of fire emblem and management games,

my actual hours to beat the campaign are probably around 50-60

i played on hard difficulty and while the early game was quite difficult,
the games power curve progressively gets easier and easier until you hit late game
and your characters become unkillable gods,that can teleport across the map and oneshot bosses,
which I wont lie is quite fun for a short time but probly the reason why the game doesnt drag on too long past final class evolutions.

the story and music are mid,but the gameplay loop of progressing your party,and doing quests,is very addicting,i was pretty much hooked the whole way from start to finish.

although i will say this game is definitely not perfect,the game is built around the idea of having multiple parties you can do quests with but there is really no point in using anything other then your main party of 6 for pretty much everything,as with most rpgs having your xp in one place is just optimal.

some of the end game class evolutions are insanely powerful and others just fall flat,in comparison 

reaper and saint are insanely powerful, whilst others like swordmaster, and stormpiercer are dissapointing in comparison

I would give it a 8/10  pretty good for the price,almost a masterpiece but not quite.

I just hope the adventurers themselves can do more by themselves alone to make their mood up and not just rely on their guild master. Like drinking in tavern, auto eating with their guild master, like a toggle so that we are open to eat with anyone.

Also a bit weird that the bed upgrade or some upgrades needs to be waited.

The part salary and bonuses. I hope we could also increase their salary? Like it will have more lasting effect rather than that bonus where it only temporarily increase.

Anyway, other than those, the game is addicting. I just really hope the adventurer have more autonomy in their mood aspect.

If you like darkest dungeon 1 you will love this. I would give it a 7/10 its a really good game, with pretty funny writing. My only complaint are a few small bugs, and the art being a little amateur. I love the inclusion of the character traits as well as sexualities for each character, it makes them all unique and feel more like people.

HOW are my wizards missing 95% three times in a row while the enemy lands a 5% crit through 12% hit chance to one shot my rogue? Did Stormtroopers infiltrate my guild? Am I being sabotaged by Darth Vader?

Aside from occasional shenanigans the game pulls, this is deceptively good for its early 2010s flash game graphics. I like it though. Reminds me of the good ol' days.

I'm hoping to see more DLCs for more variety in character builds.
Fantastic tactics game. I almost passed on it at the beginning but I'm glad I stuck it out because the mechanics for the master classes are super fun!

Interesting game. Many layers of character development, funny story elements. i would not call it a RPG, the tactical element is prevalent.  Can be a little tiring and repetitive if you try to finish it relatively fast - take breaks between sessions.

A lot of fun so far. 

It makes me feel like I'm in an anime with its humor, and some of the character attachments I'm already forming. The only downside is that you don't have dialogue options, so sometimes your character is kind of an asshole for no reason. 

The art isn't great, but I'll take it over the lazy AI shit.  Plus, the game more than makes up for it with a lot of charm.

The gameplay, vibes, mechanics are all amazing! Just the art style of characters and overall UI could use a tuneup, but as an indie dev I can imagine that's rough.

Love this game a lot, thanks for making it!

Overall, it's a great a game, and it's much better than I expected from the screenshots + description. I played at a fast pace and focused on story quests, and it took me 30 hours to beat the game. If you play at a moderate pace and do more side quests, it'll probably take 50-100h to beat it. There's enough content drip-fed throughout the game that I don't think I would've gotten bored even if I took it at a slower pace. 

I know it's a great game because after I started it, I played it 5 days in a row until I beat it. I felt sad after finishing it, and I hadn't gotten bored of the mechanics yet. This is the first RPG I've actually finished in ages. The game started out a bit slow for the first few hours, but I'm glad I kept playing. I look forward to whatever other games the creator makes. I can tell that the creator put a lot of passion into this game.

I really enjoyed the combat system. There are tons of ways you can build each individual character, tons of different character combos you can put in a party, and tons of different strategies you can run.

There are a lot of rough edges like simple graphics, some minor translation errors, and a UI that can be clunky. However, none of these significantly impacted my enjoyment of the game, and I think these mishaps can be forgiven because the game was made by a single dev with limited resources. Personally, I think the graphics are actually pretty good if I consider that single dev made all of this.

One point of feedback I have is that the non-boss combat encounters get repetitive quite quickly, because they aren't challenging and take a fair amount of time to play through. The boss encounters were almost all quite fun.

Another point of feedback is that there's not much to do after your party is strong enough to do after the final story quests. Afterwards, the only combat you can do are either side quests or the Wizard King DLC. Side quests stop scaling in difficulty at the end of the game and aren't challenging anymore. The Wizard King Tower is challenging combat-wise, and I find it somewhat fun, but it doesn't feel nearly as rewarding as the main game because it's solely combat and there's minimal story progression or new things to be unlocked. That said, most other single-player RPGs don't have much to do post-endgame either.
I was not having high hope due to the pricing but man was i wrong. This game is good. Good storytelling, game play and layout.

There is so much about this game that I love. It's got a pleasant but simple art style, it's got pretty basic RPG stuff, but done right. Very back to basics, which is a good thing. And the humor is okay. Nothing LOL funny but not cringe.

I genuinely like almost everything about this game...

But not being able to save mid-fight is ABSOLUTELY RUINING EVERYTHING. I'm having to redo the same goddamn mission over and over and over again because of unlucky crits and such. I'm leveled and geared for it, but it's a major boss battle so sometimes you just get unlucky. And sometimes you're people like me with less than no luck, and you end up going mad having to redo this same shit 80 times because I refuse to permanently lose a team member over unlucky focus-fire crits.

PLEASE allow saves during fights. I don't care how other people feel about save scumming or whatever else. I do not want to spend my free time doing the same thing over and over again.

Extremely satisfying game. Lots of options to play how you want. In my first run, I primarily built up one group with permadeath turned off and a couple more groups doing odd jobs. Plenty of different ways to build your teams! Highly recommended.
This game has a great system, cool build options, fun team building, and a great story.  Highly recommended.

Great game. Solid tactics, nice story, and lots of personality. Heroes are not static, their relationships with each other constantly change, and affect battle. The game is a bit slow at the beginning, but once heroes start leveling up and getting more skills, it really opens up and shows the gem this game is.

A great mix of SRPG and management sim
The management is fun but not as deep as the gameplay
The gameplay is fantastic
The art can look amateurish at times but its grows on you
The story was actually interesting and i enjoyed it
Overall a great game

As with many others, I was wary of Newgrounds style flash game aesthetic, but I've found a great tactics game by diving into it. It starts out simplish, but then gradually introduces more and more complexity as you progress further. It's fun.

This game was actually way too fun

pros;
The story is simple but competent
The systems work well with each other and building a unit is fun and rewarding
The combat flows nicely and doesn't really drag
The game is pretty challenging even on normal difficulty

cons:
some spelling errors
Could use more quest variety
Hard to "catch up" a new character to join an established team

I almost refunded the game within the first two hours because I was a bit torn. The graphics and UI take some getting used to, but you can tell the developer put effort into it instead of using AI. The focus is clearly on the gameplay, the classes, and the skills, although some Classes feel alot more powerful. I spent the hours over the course of a week and played it straight through.

A clear buy recommendation for the price. The game is surprisingly long, and even on Normal I had some difficulties at the beginning. In the endgame, only my main party was really useful, and they handled pretty much everything without any problems.

The management aspect is rather minimal — I would’ve liked if you could do more with the other parties besides just sending them on missions. At times it can get a bit grindy because of materials, gold, etc., and the autoplay is unfortunately pretty... incompetent.

I’m curious to see what the developer releases next. Now it’s time for the DLC and another run on a higher difficulty.

A wonderful game. While it may look like it has limited options, any little tweek, any little trait of your adventurers, all of it changes the feel of your teams noticable.

Building your adventurers and the parties they fight in is the best part to me personally. Have a well balanced group with typical tank, heal, dps? Go right ahead. Want a group of spearfighters that all combo attack to wittle down big enemies with a thousand cuts? Sure! A full support team with a single damage dealer stacked to the high heavens with buffs? Let them be the hero! Go for a street gang beating up your enemies with just fists? Also valid. Or go 'oops all mages' but take good care of the living nuke you just sent out into danger.

The combat can be a bit repetitive at times, but is far from bad, especially with how the different biomes encourage different approaches.

Despite some rough english here and there, the overall writing is really well done, the characters are likeable and both side stories as well as mainstory are quite enjoyable to read through.

Art is subjective obviously, but I really like the entire design a lot too.

This little gem offers great enjoyment for a single playthrough, but also a lot of good fun with new game+ or just a new run with different choices altogether.

I can't praise the work of this developer enough. Our Adventurer Guild is a great indie title. If what you see wakes any interest at all, give it a try, it's definitely worth it.

This game is a hidden gem for me! The first time I discovered it, I tried the trial version for about 20 minutes , then I deleted it and immediately bought the full version!

This game truly deserves a higher price and continued development. I really enjoy the party system, though I think it could use a few more features. I hope the developers keep building on this concept inthe next part of the series!

Awesome and addictive gameplay.

Additional bonus for me was scratching my Disgaea itch by allowing of stacking all bonuses on one character and creating a solo monster.

really enjoy the game. art style kind of reminds me of adventure quest..but in a good way. Enjoy the class system and building different parties and doing quests. Already recommended to multiple friends, bought the dlc to get the new class, pretty solid. looking forward to getting up in the higher level content.

This is a neat game. Not sure if overwhelmingly positive is accurate, but I'm enjoying myself so I'll give it a thumbs up too. The art is truly ugly though. It's not quite BattleOn AdventureQuest circa 2002 grade ugly, but we're getting there. I did attempt to import images for portraits, but that feature didn't work super well. But I enjoy the classes, and the gameplay loop. With some polish in writing, some tweaks to how the city management works and, of course, a major art overhaul, I'd reckon this is the kind of game which would actually benefit a bunch from a sequel. That's my opinion at least. I can recommend with the asterisk that you must be able to accept that the game is an eyesore.
This game is simple, yet inredibly fun to play. Definitely worth its money.

I cannot recommend this game enough!! for such a strange art direction to a like tabletop boardgame when you do missions it all has a certain charm, having my adventurers work together establish friendships, relationships, etc. this game scratches most itches for people looking for a turn based strategy game. if there was one thing I kinda wish this game had would be like different races to play as other than humans lol like throw elves dwarfs orcs in there and this game would be a 100/10 lol but without those things this game is a solid 10/10 and I cannot wait to continue sinking my teeth in. the creator of this game is already working on a new project and if its anything like this I will be the first in line to buy it! pick this up if you love turn based strategy games!

This game could get a thumbs up just from the banter between the Guild Master and Fiola. But its good in the gameplay sense as well.

If I have one solid complaint, its that the AI can't select attacks specific for enemy weaknesses. Doesn't seem like it would be that hard to get the AI to do, and yet that's why you have to wrangle some missions that could otherwise be done on auto.
I only hope that they make another game like this with a bigger budget. This game is extremely fun and has good replay value.

I really enjoying this game...build a squad manage their injuries and happiness and work on maximizing its effectiveness through diversity of roles and abilities....the story is decent but I would prefer a more nonlinear sandbox mode to a story....but the story is decent....the game play is kinda like Final Fantasy tactics style....I like the style....the management functions are great I like the dynamics of managing costs of the adventures verse keeping them happy and healthy....and the interrelationships between them adds more to the enjoyment....for the low cost of this game I got my moneys worth....

I would give this game a 8 out of 10 rating based on price and how much I enjoyed it...

The downsides are:

- The graphics need improving....the art and game field graphics are okay but improving them would really make the game pop...

- the game play needs more random events and different types....I would even think making it so when a random event comes up the player has to make a decision that will impact the positive and negatives of the random event...and the results could be something like guild master experience/luck...giving the guild master some sort of buildable stats that impact the guild as a whole or the events would bring in a new dynamic

- Need more variety of mazes/dungeons would be great....seems to me you have 3 (Forest, old fort, Caves) that just get bigger based on the difficulty level but otherwise the same....making a variety maybe with more types of objectives would again add a more engaging dynamic

- Allowing guild master relationship effect quests types would also be nice.....rather just random events showing up.... having the guild master do things/quests for the npc should create new possible quests and stats gains...

Again, I'm sorry if this sounds negative overall I love the game and love the concept I just see what it could be and I can't help but put it out there.  To the creator, I hope you keep expanding this game its a good game and you did good work....I keep an eye out to see what comes next...

Raw unfiltered Kino, pure, distilled, premium grade stuff, if this were the 90s there would be 30 dead Columbians surrounding this game due to its primo quality and desirable product, if I had to choose between this game and a burning bus full of pre-schoolers, it would be this game every time.

This game has a lot going for it, starts to get a little repetitive but I have been playing it for hours at a time.

My main issue and what has me nearly quitting this game:

95% chance to hit misses on 75% of attempts. It's flabbergasting how often 95% misses. It's freaking crazy, averaging about 3 misses per fight at 95%. I have had 95% chances miss back to back dozens of times and THREE TIMES IN A ROW a handful of times. Statistically impossible.

As an "adventuring guild sim", it's decent and relatively straightforward. Keep people happy (or at least not sad), send your little manz out, direct said manz as you gather stuff and beat up bad guys. A lot of going out and gathering resources or thinning out baddies.

Now, the dialogue? Between "decent" and "hilarious". The non-adventurer NPCs are colorful and interesting. The art for them is "first manga", but the character designs make it worth it.

I'm enjoying it. 19 hours in, I'm still interested (although I did restart once because of course I did), and if they did a sequel with more open-world options I'd buy it all again.
Great tactical RPG from a small dev. If you like FFT give this a shot.

Hits the FE3H/Valkyria/XCOM itch of having an organization to manage and heroes to nurture. Fantastic debut release for the green person. The art is hard to look at sometimes, mainly the portraits and npcs. Great pacing and balance. Could use some travel time for quests. Limited counters is the perfect solution to FE one man armies. Relationship mechanics are tight. Party/Team building is clean. Morale is a fantastic way to push your heroes to the limit. Would like to see long term injuries and traits coming out of combat. Well worth the price. Hope this green individual works on a bigger budget project for their next game.

Nitpicks:
Why have holy damage when healing is far stronger vs undead and heals.

Genuinely one of the biggest surprises I've had in gaming in as long as I can remember.  Somehow a single guy made one of the best SRPGs in years.  This is the type of indie game that needs to be supported.

You play as a guild master of a simple adventurer's guild down on its luck, and try to reclaim your former glory while also finding out dark secrets regarding the former guild master's (and your best friend) mysterious death.  A pretty interesting story that keeps you interested throughout the game even if its a very simplistic "good vs evil" story.  The characters are also all entertaining and well fleshed out.

The gameplay is very deep.  There are essentially two major phases to the game, the "management sim" aspect where you manage your guild by caring for your adventurers.  This is setup as a list of menus around your base where you can hire/train/equip/heal and organize your adventurers.  You also unlock different features in the base throughout the game's story.  The game almost NEVER stops drip feeding you things to upgrade and unlock.  It's part of what makes it so great.  It doesn't run out of steam.

The adventurers themselves are basically your RPG party members.  They have a stat sheet that will remind a lot of people of fire emblem and each of those stats affects their functional battle stats in various different ways.  Each time they level up, there's a percentage chance that stat will increase.  This increase varies WILDLY between different adventurers based on what traits they have.  Each one is randomly generated in the hiring menu.  You'll never get sick of looking through the hiring menu whenever it refreshes with new adventurers looking for interesting combinations that can make very powerful characters.  This combination of randomly generated traits and the stat growth system make character building so interesting.  I should probably mention there's also a "class" or "job" system for all these characters.  Each class has very unique stats and skills that make none of them redundant - they all have a different purpose and fulfill them masterfully.  With the DLC release that added a couple extra classes there are a LOT of different character archetypes that you can mix and match now.  

The combination of different classes plus the limited character deployment in each mission requires you to have a wide variety of characters that do different things.  Each mission you do with adventurers also applies a mood debuff on them or injuries that penalize their max health if they took damage that force you to rotate through multiple characters and teams.  The teams themselves can even be customized to have unique relationships within themselves and with other teams.  The fun never stops!  

That's a tiny little view of the management aspect of the game, the other parts of the game don't slouch either.  Each mission you undertake is displayed almost like a board game where you move your "piece" (your adventurer party) around a grid through a small randomly generated dungeon.  You can interact with resources to collect things, and there are roaming monster parties that will hunt you down to initiate combat. You can also run into randomly generated events that can give your party members unique and powerful traits or curses.  Part of the fun of the game is rolling with the punches, I HIGHLY recommend playing with the iron man setting on so you can't save scum.

Combat takes place in a grid style turn based strategy RPG.  If you've played tactics ogre you'll be right at home here, it's very very similar from that aspect.  One of the biggest differences from tactics ogre is that every character in the combat has a chance to go each turn, the order is just separated by their speed or "initiative" value.  The gameplay here is pretty garden variety (more characters through cells to do things to the enemies), but has enough to chew on to keep you entertained.  The big payoff is seeing your adventurers growing and becoming strong to the point where they can do absurd things in combat like delete an entire enemy combat group alone in a single turn.  There's a lot to explore, and because the game continues to unlock new weapons, armor, items, classes, etc throughout the game you're continually unlocking new interesting things to do in combat.

About the only downside of the game, is the art style is kind of scuffed and the music and sound fx are generic.  The art style does grow on you a little.

It is relatively simple, with a lot of options for customization. The story is good, and there is a clear line of progression. The ability to field multiple adventure parties is pretty awesome. I was a bit frustrated at first at the length of time for healing, until I realized the point of it was to vary your parties, and to level up multiple rather than focusing on just one. After a couple brutal deaths from unexpected occurrences, I realized the importance of leveling more people. Managing moods actually seems to help promote multiple groups as well. 
This game features a guild management system, where you manage an adventure guild with multiple parties. Combat is strategic squad based with initiative system. There is a good variety of things to do, and the gameplay loop is pretty fun. You can make this as difficult as you want, and it can definitely be brutal. 

I look forward to your sequel. As much fun/time as I've spent in this game, buying that will be a given.

Our Adventurer Guild surprised me. I expected a light tactics game, but what I got was a thoughtful mix of strategy, management, and storytelling. You’re not just commanding a party; you’re running an entire guild filled with personalities, flaws, and ambitions. Every decision matters, and the consequences hit harder than you’d expect.

Combat is simple to learn but deeply tactical. Positioning, morale, and timing make every fight feel intense, and the Bravery system adds real tension. Losing a mission stings, but it always feels fair.

The real magic comes from the small moments. Adventurers argue, grow, get injured, and sometimes never come back. Those stories make every run memorable. The art and music tie it all together with a warm but bittersweet tone.

If you like tactical RPGs that make you care about your team and think before every move, this game is worth your time.

Don't let the graphics fool you. This game is really good! It combines elements from Final Fantasy Tactics (battles, jobs), Darkest Dungeon (perma-death, dungeon structure), D&D (skill trees, skill checks), and, dare I say, does so flawlessly. I've wanted a great, deep guild management game for a while now and this game hit the nail on the head. Since I'm an old man, I really love the Flash game-style graphics. It feels like you found a Newgrounds game that actually had the resources to make a brilliant product. This game is definitely worth your money.

Scratches an XCOM-but-as-a-fantasy-rougelite sort of itch, 35 hours deep and still mid-level (Though i wander off and do housework and cook sometimes). I'm having lots of fun working if it's possible to imbalance the game significantly by over-leveraging character development variances but also becoming quite fond of the members of the 5 parties I have rolling around righting wrongs all over the place. 

So far gameplay complexity and combat scale is grand enough, standard turn based strategic combat grid encounters, short and snappy, with exploration and opportunities to rest between with a home base to develop alongside your characters with the loot you bring home. Positive so far but higher level is where these sorts of systems start to creak so if I remember to I will circle back and update once I have got that far. Be wary of the odd encounter that is there to keep you humble. Usually it is a random encounter which just happens to exploit a gap in your party skill mix somehow and can quickly lead to the death of a poorly positioned light or medium armoured party member. This game does not mess about with punishing leaving any individual overexposed and vulnerable. If it can kill someone it will. It will even swarm to a vulnerable threat over closer targets. I do it all the time to the enemy so I actually respect that. 

Base developments is fun but chat interactions are somehow painful, the timing windows of the click through's to proceed and how long before they appear or something like that is the root. I just know the bit of me that hates having unresolved alerts hates the bit of me that wants to refuse to engage in npc interaction chat at all unless it seems like it will drive the plot forwards. 

Has a neat longer mission structure mechanic where groups of characters head out to complete a task for a few days and are unavailable for combat during their absence. Benefits of completing these include XP, loot, specific abilities, etc.

Now, the demand for a space bar press now and then can annoy. Despite being a completely mouse driven game it now and then asks for exclusively key input. I know I could probably mess with settings for this but it seems so clunky and unneeded and somehow interrupts your flow so much. Not sure why this has frustrated me so. I didn't realise it was bothering me that much until I started typing about it. 

I'm really not a huge fan of the art style, I am here for something which puts me in mind of the 4th edition of a very, very famous ttrpg. The style just jars a bit and makes me feel like I am playing a Delicious in Dungeon licence. It works perfectly well at achieving what it sets out to do, just not my thing.

So a very fun, tactical turn and grid based combat game that has more in common with a ttrpg like D&D than it does the aforementioned XCOM, and because it does that well I am willing to put up with some clunky design choices and art which doesn't work for me. Overall this is pretty high praise as I can be really fussy, if I can be bothered to stick around for a bit under a week of work despite the annoyances it is probably a very good game. Going back to play it now.

They say you shouldn't judge a book by its cover, and this game's cover is hideous -- from the bad anime art (squashed heads on huge bodies) to the assets that look like they were sourced from some royalty free folder, it's clear that the developer did not consider presentation a high priority. In fact, I wonder if this developer (among others) has taken the wrong lesson away from the success of something like Nubby's Number Factory -- that game has awful art and people loved it anyway, yes, but the awful art in that case is an artistic choice that contributes to a cohesive aesthetic, rather than an excuse to direct effort elsewhere when making the game.

Anyway, back to the topic of judging book covers, I really wanted to give the game a fair chance, and in terms of gameplay, it's not bad. It borrows elements of Final Fantasy Tactics, Darkest Dungeon, and Wildermyth (particularly having a roster of randomized heroes who go through emergent stories), though it might be more accurate to say the game attempts to imitate a tabletop RPG experience like D&D or Pathfinder. This especially comes across with skill checks, which are rolled with an animated d20 Baldur's Gate style, but the influence can also be seen in the grid-based combat, the hero level progression, and even the combat appearance of the heroes and enemies as little tabletop miniatures.

While the gameplay is reminiscent of D&D, the writing is reminiscent of a D&D session played by a gaggle of teenage boys, with all the storytelling prowess and maturity that implies. It's quite bad, showing off effort on par with what was put into the art. If you don't mind extreme silliness and a plethora of unfunny jokes (or if that's the sort of vibe you like at your D&D table), you may be able to look past this and get enjoyment out of this game. I could not, especially since I couldn't help but compare the game to the likes of Darkest Dungeon and Wildermyth, which both have phenomenal writing (not to mention great art).

In the end, the most damning thing about Our Adventurer Guild wasn't the art, nor was it the writing, at least not by themselves. If this game was really excellent and put its own spin on tried-and-true mechanics, I could probably stick with it. As it was, though, I felt like the game wasn't doing anything particularly novel -- I ultimately decided I wasn't excited about doing a gameloop I was already intimately familiar with using a new crop of mediocre-at-best content. (If you're debating playing this game and haven't tried Wildermyth, do yourself a favor and try Wildermyth. It's a million times better than this.)

They say you shouldn't judge a book by its cover, and this game's cover is hideous -- from the bad anime art (squashed heads on huge bodies) to the assets that look like they were sourced from some royalty free folder, it's clear that the developer did not consider presentation a high priority. In fact, I wonder if this developer (among others) has taken the wrong lesson away from the success of something like Nubby's Number Factory -- that game has awful art and people loved it anyway, yes, but the awful art in that case is an artistic choice that contributes to a cohesive aesthetic, rather than an excuse to direct effort elsewhere when making the game.

Anyway, back to the topic of judging book covers, I really wanted to give the game a fair chance, and in terms of gameplay, it's not bad. It borrows elements of Final Fantasy Tactics, Darkest Dungeon, and Wildermyth (particularly having a roster of randomized heroes who go through emergent stories), though it might be more accurate to say the game attempts to imitate a tabletop RPG experience like D&D or Pathfinder. This especially comes across with skill checks, which are rolled with an animated d20 Baldur's Gate style, but the influence can also be seen in the grid-based combat, the hero level progression, and even the combat appearance of the heroes and enemies as little tabletop miniatures.

While the gameplay is reminiscent of D&D, the writing is reminiscent of a D&D session played by a gaggle of teenage boys, with all the storytelling prowess and maturity that implies. It's quite bad, showing off effort on par with what was put into the art. If you don't mind extreme silliness and a plethora of unfunny jokes (or if that's the sort of vibe you like at your D&D table), you may be able to look past this and get enjoyment out of this game. I could not, especially since I couldn't help but compare the game to the likes of Darkest Dungeon and Wildermyth, which both have phenomenal writing (not to mention great art).

In the end, the most damning thing about Our Adventurer Guild wasn't the art, nor was it the writing, at least not by themselves. If this game was really excellent and put its own spin on tried-and-true mechanics, I could probably stick with it. As it was, though, I felt like the game wasn't doing anything particularly novel -- I ultimately decided I wasn't excited about doing a gameloop I was already intimately familiar with using a new crop of mediocre-at-best content. They say you shouldn't judge a book by its cover, and this game's cover is hideous -- from the bad anime art (squashed heads on huge bodies) to the assets that look like they were sourced from some royalty free folder, it's clear that the developer did not consider presentation a high priority. In fact, I wonder if this developer (among others) has taken the wrong lesson away from the success of something like Nubby's Number Factory -- that game has awful art and people loved it anyway, yes, but the awful art in that case is an artistic choice that contributes to a cohesive aesthetic, rather than an excuse to direct effort elsewhere when making the game.

Anyway, back to the topic of judging book covers, I really wanted to give the game a fair chance, and in terms of gameplay, it's not bad. It borrows elements of Final Fantasy Tactics, Darkest Dungeon, and Wildermyth (particularly having a roster of randomized heroes who go through emergent stories), though it might be more accurate to say the game attempts to imitate a tabletop RPG experience like D&D or Pathfinder. This especially comes across with skill checks, which are rolled with an animated d20 Baldur's Gate style, but the influence can also be seen in the grid-based combat, the hero level progression, and even the combat appearance of the heroes and enemies as little tabletop miniatures.

While the gameplay is reminiscent of D&D, the writing is reminiscent of a D&D session played by a gaggle of teenage boys, with all the storytelling prowess and maturity that implies. It's quite bad, showing off effort on par with what was put into the art. If you don't mind extreme silliness and a plethora of unfunny jokes (or if that's the sort of vibe you like at your D&D table), you may be able to look past this and get enjoyment out of this game. I could not, especially since I couldn't help but compare the game to the likes of Darkest Dungeon and Wildermyth, which both have phenomenal writing (not to mention great art).

In the end, the most damning thing about Our Adventurer Guild wasn't the art, nor was it the writing, at least not by themselves. If this game was really excellent and put its own spin on tried-and-true mechanics, I could probably stick with it. As it was, though, I felt like the game wasn't doing anything particularly novel -- I ultimately decided I wasn't excited about doing a gameloop I was already intimately familiar with using a new crop of mediocre-at-best content. (If you're debating playing this game and haven't tried Wildermyth, do yourself a favor and try Wildermyth. It's a million times better than this.)
